By Kurasu Soratobu on Tuesday, December 30, 2003 - 05:02 pm:

'Real' was a joker-only special in MR2. It raised all your monster's stats, but lowered them when 'Real' wore off. I've watched my monster's guts regen and movement speed go up when it got Real (a Naga/Hengar, in my case), so I suspect it's probably the same thing.

By Kurasu Soratobu on Wednesday, December 31, 2003 - 01:21 am:

A little more detail on how 'poison' works. It makes the monster lose 1% of their HP until it wears off. This is rounded down, and it goes by _present_ HP rather than _maximum_ HP. So a monster with 100 HP will lose only 1 HP to poison, while one with 245HP will lose 2HP per turn until it wears off, or until they get to 199, upon which time they'll lose only 1 per. A monster with less than 100 HP left is unaffected by poison's HP loss. If there's any other effects by poison, I've yet to notice them.

By Kurasu Soratobu on Wednesday, December 31, 2003 - 07:46 am:

I know. A lot of stuff one after the other, but I'm playing at different times. I'm hoping the editing will clean it up. :)

'Caution' does not directly influence the hit-rate of the enemy monster. I had a Ripper/Joker use it, and my monster's hit rate stayed the same (65% before it was used, up to 67% after because of guts, and still 67% after it wore off). I think it probably does what it did in MRA2: gives an automatic dodge. Therefore, no matter how high your hit percentage is, the monster will get out of the way as long as they're 'Cautioned'.

Plus, same monster got slowed. My hit rate did not go up, but their movement rate did go down. I had no problems moving to whatever range I wanted while they were slowed. I also hit directly afterward, so it's possible that it makes the next hit automatic, but with a 64% chance to hit, it's hard to tell for certain.

By D knight on Wednesday, December 31, 2003 - 03:04 pm:

ive hit monsters under caution so it is not an automatic miss. curently im thinking it gives a boost to the monsters speed and this usually makes the opponents accuracy drop but once a monster achieves a certain speed level or the opponent reaches a certain accuracy level the change is less noticable.

also from what i have seen the only effect of slow is that the monster doesnt move as fast makeing it easier to move toward or away from him.
